description:
Crocidura indochinensis, also known as the Indochinese white-toothed shrew, is a small mammal species belonging to the family Soricidae. It is native to Southeast Asia, found in countries such as Vietnam, Laos, and Cambodia.

This shrew is characterized by its small size, typically measuring around 8-10 cm in body length. It has a slender, elongated body and a pointed snout, which is a common feature among shrews. The fur coloration is generally grayish-brown on the dorsal (upper) side and grayish-white on the ventral (lower) side.

Crocidura indochinensis is an insectivorous species, feeding primarily on a variety of small invertebrates, including insects, spiders, and other arthropods. It is a nocturnal and solitary creature, spending the majority of its time foraging for food and seeking shelter in burrows, crevices, or leaf litter.

The species is considered to have a relatively wide distribution in its native range, but its population status and conservation needs are not well-studied. Ongoing habitat loss and fragmentation due to human activities, such as deforestation and urbanization, may pose potential threats to the long-term survival of this shrew species in its natural environment.
